MYERS, Chief of the Signal corps. which got organized in the very crisis of the fever of our military experiment and expenditure, was relieved yesterday and ordered to Memphis then to report back here to the Adjutant-General. The property of the corps has been turned over to Capt. NICODEMUS, except the field telegraphic force and materials and trains, which have been assigned to duty under Col. ANSON STAGER, of the Military Telegraph. The expenditure of the Signal corps is said to be five thousand dollars a day -- and this is the reason given for sending this new exile to our cotton-growing Siberia.

WASHINGTON, November 15. There has been reconnaissance of our forces along the Rapidan at Raccoon Ford. An advance in force of Gen. Longstreet has occurred on Gen. Burnside's force. our forces are retreating to Knoxville, Tennessee. Corpus Christi, Texas, has been captured by Gen. Banks' troops. From the Richmond Enquirer, Nov. 3. The Atlantic telegraph cable is certainly to be tried again. It appears that the indefatigable Mr. CYRUS FIELD has just come over from England to New-York, bringing a specimen of the new cable manufactured by Messrs. GLASS, ELLIOTS ES CO., and Yankees are largely taking stock.

WASHINGTON, November 14. Rebel Gen. Longstreet crossed the Tennessee River in his march against Knoxville, Tennessee. SAN FRANCISCO, Tuesday, Nov. 10. A fire at Nevada City yesterday destroyed nearly all the buildings on Broad-street, five brick buildings on Main-street, the Episcopal, Methodist, Congregational and Catholic Churches, the theatre, Court-house, express and telegraph offices, the gas works, the United States Hotel and many stores in the neighborhood. The County records were saved. The loss is estimated at SX 200,000.

WASHINGTON, November 13. It is reported to-day on authority of the surgeons in the Army of the Potomac, that our losses on Saturday were about 400, as stated in the Press telegram last night. 260 of these who are wounded, arrived here this morning, and were placed in the hospital. The premises of the Old Capitol Prison are densely crowded to-day, 1,730 rebel prisoners that were taken in Saturday's engagements having reached here up to 2 o'clock this morning. The Star of this city says: QN We hear that Gen. GRANT has telegraphed hither that two of the most advanced positions of Gen. BURNSIDE have been assailed and captured by the rebels.

NEW YORK, November 12. The laborers, car-drivers, and conductors went on strike to-day in New York City. The cars have been stopped on some of the city's railroads. A body of rebel cavalry crossed the Tennessee River and destroyed two railroad bridges near Lynnville, Tennessee. MEMPHIS, Sunday, Nov. 8. The rebel General RICHARDSON struck the Memphis and Charleston Railroad six miles east of Salisbury yesterday morning, destroyed the railroad bridge at Middletown, burned two small bridges, tore up several miles of track, and cut the telegraph badly. The latter was repaired this morning. The former will be in running order to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, November 11. To-day there was formal presentation to Gen. Meade of the battle flags captured in the battle on the evening of the 7th. Lord Lyons officially informed the Government at Washington that he had received information from the Governor-General of Canada of a plot to invade the United States from Canada, destroy the City of Buffalo, and liberate the rebel prisoners on Johnson's Island in Lake Erie. Gen. Butler has assumed command of the Departments of Eastern Virginia and North Carolina, headquarters at Fortress Monroe. Gen. Foster took leave of his command to-day at Fortress Monroe.

WASHINGTON, November 10. Rebel report from ATLANTA, Wednesday, Nov. 4. The Yankees maintain possession of Raccoon Valley, having been heavily reinforced. From Richmond papers of Friday received at Fortress Monroe, we obtain the following: The Yankees shell our forces incessantly. The floods in Tennessee have demolished all the Yankee pontoons. The Yankee advance has reached Florence. The enemy are raiding the country near Huntsville, committing great depredations. Their raids are more disastrous than any of their preceding ones in Madison and Huntsville Counties. BRAGG has it in his power to muzzle the telegraph, but he cannot muzzle the mails.

WASHINGTON, November 9. Reconnaissance has occurred to Culpepper, Virginia. Gen. Meade has issued a congratulatory order to his troops on their successful passage of the Rappahannock. PHILADELPHIA, Friday, Nov. 6. There are reports of a terrible riot in the coal regions around Mauch Chunk. Four men, it is reported, were killed last evening. Gov. CURTIN, it is stated, has been telegraphed to for troops to quell the disturbance. THOMAS HULL, of the firm of HULL, SMITH ES CORLIES, has received a dispatch from Summit, Penn., that GEORGE K. SMITH, of that firm, has been shot dead by the rioters. Mr. ULRICH, storekeeper, was also fired at by the rioters.

WASHINGTON, November 8. A cavalry fight has occurred at Hazel Run, Virginia. Gen. Meade reported that on advancing from Kelly's Ford, in the morning, it was discovered that the rebels had evacuated their position on the Rappahannock. Our army was put in motion and the pursuit of the rebels continued by the infantry to Brandy Station, and by the cavalry beyond. Our captures in the fight at Rappahannock were four guns, eight battle flags, and over 1,900 prisoners. The rebel steamer Cornubia has been captured at Wilmington, North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, November 7. To-day there was a battle on the banks of the Rappahannock, near Rappahannock station. our army was very successful, capturing rebel redoubts and taking 2,000 prisoners. The reconnaissance of the Chowan River, North Carolina, is reportedly continuing. Received from Richmond and published this morning is an official list of the Union officers now confined in the Confederate States military prison at Richmond, with the places and date of their capture. This important document has recently been furnished to our Government by the Confederate authorities. Its publication will not only furnish much information, but will relieve the anxieties of many persons.

WASHINGTON, November 6. An engagement occurred to-day in West Virginia. Reconnaissance has occurred on the Chowan River, North Carolina, to near the mouth of the Blackwater. Damages to the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, effected by the rebels recently, are being repaired. Eleven miles of the road was reconstructed in seven days. Among the items of work performed were 653 linear feet of bridges, varying from 20 to 65 feet in height. 27,700 ties were prepared and laid sufficient to make a string of timber 45 miles long. The destruction of the road by the rebels was most thorough. Telegraph poles were cut down and the telegraph wire destroyed.

NEW YORK, November 5. There is a ball in New York city to-day to honor the Russians. WASHINGTON, November 5. A skirmish has occurred at Metley's Ford, Tennessee. The steamer Margaret and Jesse has been captured by the Fulton. Gen. Averill has attacked and defeated the enemy near Lewisburgh, capturing three pieces of artillery, 100 prisoners, and a large number of small arms, wagons, and a large quantity of camp equipage. The enemy's loss in killed and wounded is estimated at 300.

WASHINGTON, November 4. Brownsville, Texas, has been captured by Gen. Banks' army. ATLANTA, Friday, Oct. 30. No new reports from above by telegraph. The following has been received by mail: MISSIONARY RIDGE, Thursday, Oct. 29. The enemy have crossed a division at Brown's Ferry, three miles below Chattanooga, and are in possession of Raccoon Mountain, which they are apparently fortifying. A rapid shelling of our camps on the west side of Lookout Mountain was kept up by the enemy to-day, our batteries replying. No casualties reported. Heavy skirmishing anticipated on the left.

WASHINGTON, November 3. Elections have occurred in New-York, New-Jersey, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, and Wisconsin. The Union ticket has been successful in all states but one. A reconnaissance operation has occurred to Falmouth, Virginia. Rebels have been repulsed at Colliersville, Tennessee. A battle occurred to-day at Bayou Coteau in the Teche country, Louisiana. NEWARK, N.J., Monday, Nov. 2. A collision occurred on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, between Trenton and Tacony, on Sunday afternoon. GEORGE S. SPELLMAN, a telegraph operator, had both his legs broken.

WASHINGTON, November 2. Brazos Island, Texas, is now occupied by Federal forces and Boca Chica has been captured by Gen. Banks' army. The Convention of the National Telegraphic Union will be held this evening. The Delegates to the Convention will meet at 8 o'clock, at the Everett House, in the City of New-York, for the purpose of completing the organization of the QN Union, QN adopting a Constitution and Bye-Laws, and electing a President and other officers for the ensuing year, and transacting such other business as may come before the Convention. The proprietors of the Everett House have most kindly tendered the use of a room for holding the sessions of the Convention.

WASHINGTON, November 1. A plot to liberate rebel prisoners in Ohio was discovered. WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct 28. JOHN H. O'NEILL, United States Military Telegraph Operator, of Pittsburgh, Penn., a gentleman deservedly esteemed, died this evening in Alexandria, Va., of typhoid fever, aged 23 years. ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, Tuesday, Oct. 27, 1863. No battle occurred yesterday, as was confidently anticipated by many persons whose opportunities for knowing all the secrets of the service are considered good. The enemy, however, still show a bold front north of the Rappahannock, and no one can foresee what an hour may bring forth.

UTICA, NEW YORK, Friday, Oct. 30, 1863. The Special train from Albany, bearing the Russians route for Niagara Falls, reached here early yesterday morning. The train consisted of four passenger cars, a lunch car and baggage car, and is under the charge of conductor B.B. YATES, who puts the Russians through at the rate of 45 miles an hour, running time. He reached Niagara Falls at 5 P.M. All the towns have greeted the Russians with waving handkerchiefs. Before leaving Niagara Falls, this morning, the officers of the Russian fleet went down in a body from the Cataract House to the stairs leading to the ferry at the foot of the American Falls, for a photographic image.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Oct. 30. Nothing additional to what has already been telegraphed has been received at the headquarters of the army up to noon to-day concerning HOOKER's victory. The fight took place at Brown's Ferry, on the Tennessee River, near Chattanooga, and the result is considered of the highest importance, as it removes the rebel obstructions to steamboat navigation to that point, and secures other advantages in opening up the way for army supplies. At 9 o'clock yesterday morning, Maj.-Gen. THOMAS telegraphed to the War Department as follows: Gen. HOOKER was attacked at 12 o'clock, midnight, and a severe fight ensued which continued for two hours.

CHATTANOOGA, Wednesday, Oct. 28, Via NASHVILLE, Thursday, Oct. 29. Lookout Mountain was yesterday taken by our forces, the enemy falling back without resistance. Our troops occupy the south bank of the river from Bridgeport to Chattanooga, and the river and railroad are unobstructed. L.L. CROUNSE. NASHVILLE, Thursday, Oct. 29. Lookout Mountain was taken on the 28th by our troops, under Gen. HOOKER, with the Eleventh corps and a portion of the Twelfth, and PALMER's division of the Fourth corps. There was no serious opposition.

WASHINGTON, October 28. There has been a furious bombardment of Fort Sumter to-day. Confederate President Jefferson DAVIS, as he was returning from his visit to BRAGG's army, made a speech at Selma, Ala., on the 18th inst., and we find a telegraphic abstract of it in our Southern files. In the course of it he touched upon the foreign relations of the Confederacy, and remarked: QN Self-reliance and energy is now our only duty. we should not look to Europe for aid, for such is not to be expected now. QN So JEFF. DAVIS has at last given up what has been one of his fondest hopes ever since the rebellion broke out -- hope of aid from abroad.

WASHINGTON, October 27. Shells were thrown into Charleston, South Carolina, by Gen. Gillmore. NASHVILLE, Sunday, Oct. 25. There is no news of importance from Chattanooga. HOOKER's force has crossed the Tennessee River and fighting was reported yesterday. The telegraph was cut this morning, but is now working. The river is rising, and is five feet on the shoals. There have been no arrivals by the river. Gen. ROSECRANS left for Cincinnati at noon.

WASHINGTON, October 26. Skirmishing occurred to-day along the lines of the Army of the Potomac. The bombardment of Fort Sumter is renewed. Gen. Hooker has moved from Bridgeport, Tennessee. The military telegraph between Chattanooga and Nashville has been closed to the Press. A dispatch to the Cincinnati Gazette, dated Chattanooga, Oct. 24, says that Gen. GRANT arrived there on the 23d inst. Deserters report BRECKINRIDGE and HINDMAN's forces to have withdrawn from our front and moving in large bodies to our left. The object of the movement was not clear. Rumors say that Rome and Atlanta have been attacked in the rear.

WASHINGTON, October 25. WASHINGTON, Friday, Oct. 23. Major Gen. MEADE, after a brief visit to Washington, returned to his headquarters to-day. Cavalry reconnoissances are continuing on our part as far as the Rappahannock. The Orange and Alexandria Railroad has already been repaired one mile beyond Bristoe Station. Forces are engaged day and night in repairing the damages of the enemy. Reports from the army say the discipline and morale of the army were never better than at the present time, and both officers and men have the greatest confidence in the ability of Gen. MEADE.

WASHINGTON, October 24. NASHVILLE, Tenn., Tuesday, Oct. 20. Quartermaster-General MEIGS and Staff arrived here this evening. He reports that Gen. GRANT assumes the command of the Department of the Cumberland, Tennessee and Ohio, to be called the Military Division of Mississippi. Gen. THOMAS, it is reported, is to command the Army of the Cumberland. Gen. HOOKER is at Stevenson, Ala. E.M. STANTON, the Secretary of War, has arrived here on a special train. He is the guest of Judge CATRON. A railroad accident occurred at Murfreesboro, killing and wounding several. The telegraph is working to Chattanooga.

WASHINGTON, October 23. Dr. Wright was executed to-day at Norfolk, Virginia. Dr. Wright had shot a Federal officer dead after the doctor made a comment unbecoming of negro soldiers and the officer attempted to slap Dr. Wright on the cheek with his sword. The Signal corps has earned additional honors during the late campaign. it first discovered the movements of the enemy from the Rapidan to Madison Court-house, and thence, via Sperryville, to Warrenton, thus enabling Gen. MEADE to take such measures as resulted in defeating LEE's plans. The corps attached to the Army of the Potomac is under the direction of Capt. NORTON.

WASHINGTON, October 22. A cavalry skirmish occurred to-day near Fayetteville, Virginia. WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 21. Accounts from the Army of the Potomac, up to 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, furnish us with the following highly important intelligence: Gen. KILPATRICK's cavalry division, yesterday, pushed back Gen. STUART's rebel cavalry beyond Gainesville toward Warrenton. There was considerable fighting, but no considerable loss on our side. Gen. LEE, it is positively stated, was at Warrenton on Monday, and had formed his line of battle and posted his artillery.

WASHINGTON, October 21. A battle reportedly occurred to-day near Tuscumbia, Alabama. There has been a fight near Philadelphia, Tennessee, and a cavalry skirmish near Sulphur Springs, Virginia. HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, Saturday Evening, Oct. 17, 1863. The recent movements of the two great armies now confronting each other in Virginia are not without interest, particularly by reason of the science and skill displayed by the Commanding Generals, and the indomitable energy manifested by the men composing both armies. Within five days, these two formidable bodies have traversed a distance of between seventy and eighty mile.

WASHINGTON, October 20. Gov. Seymour issued a proclamation in response to that of the president calling for troops. Gen. George H. Thomas assumed command of the Army of the Cumberland. ST. LOUIS, Tuesday, Oct. 20. Little Rock advices to the 14th, state that the rebel army is scattered in every direction, and an extraordinary revival of Union sentiment has taken place among the people. Over one thousand men joined the Federal army at Little Rock, and the people were coming in daily and taking the oath of allegiance. The official report of the capture of the Confederate steamers on the Red River will not differ materially from the accounts already telegraphed.

WASHINGTON, October 19. Gen. Rosecrans relinquished his command of the Army of the Cumberland to-day. BUFFALO, Oct. 19. -- The schr. S.E. Hudson, with wheat from Milwaukee for this port, collided yesterday morning with the propeller Eclipse 42 miles above Buffalo, sinking the schooner and drowning one man. The vessel and cargo a total loss. The propeller not damaged.

WASHINGTON, October 18. Gen Grant has assumed command of the Departments of the Ohio, Cumberland, and Tennessee. Charlestown, Virginia, has been attacked by the rebels. Secretary of War Stanton has arrived in Louisville, Kentucky. CAIRO, Sunday, Oct. 18. The Memphis Bulletin, of the 16th, has information from a Union refugee, just escaped from the bloodhounds of the rebel conscriptors in Mississippi, that JOE. JOHNSTON's force, with the exception of one division, had been sent to reinforce BRAGG, and that there were not over 10,000 rebel troops in Mississippi. Gen. LORING was at Canton on the 8th, with 5,000 infantry.

WASHINGTON, October 17. A spirited engagement occurred at Manassas Junction this morning. The president has called for 300,000 volunteers to be raised before the 5th of January, stating that a draft would then take place for any deficiency in the quotas of the States existing at that time. NEW-ORLEANS, Friday, Oct. 9, 1863. Upon the heels of the conscription order, comes out Brig.-Gen. SHEPLEY's notification to the taxpayers, by which, on a certain day, an alphabetical list of all the delinquent tax-payers in New-Orleans is to be published, and after a certain time all property of the delinquents is to be seized and sold.

WASHINGTON, October 16. Gen. Grant has been ordered to the command of the Departments of the Ohio, the Cumberland, and the Tennessee. There has been a rebel raid into Brownsville, Missouri. ST. LOUIS, MO., Monday, Oct. 12. SHELBY's and COFFEY's raiders left the Pacific Railroad Saturday, moved north and reached Booneville yesterday morning. They burned no railroad property at Tipton, as previously reported, but plundered the town of a large amount of money. The citizens of Warfield, Greenfield, and other towns though which the rebels passed, suffered in a like manner. The Federal troops from several directions are closing in on them.

WASHINGTON, October 15. ST. LOUIS, Saturday, Oct. 10. Telegraphic communication was interrupted about thirty miles west of Jefferson City last night, by rebel raiders having struck the Pacific Railroad at that point. They are marching eastward, and accounts of this morning place them five miles east of Tipton. The fortifications of Sedalia have been strengthened with baled hay, and every preparation has been made for the defense of that post. It is not known yet whether the rebels have done any damage to the Pacific Railroad.

WASHINGTON, October 14. A battle has occurred at Broad River or Bristoe Station, Virginia. ST. LOUIS, Saturday, Oct. 10. The Democrat's (Leavenworth) special gives the particulars of the attack on Gen. BLUNT and his escort below Fort Scott. He was attacked by 300 rebels in Federal uniform, near the encampment of Lieut. POND. His escort broke, and out of 100 men, seventy-eight were killed -- all shot through the head, evidently after they were captured. Maj. CURTIS, son of Gen. CURTIS, was thrown from his horse, and was found with a bullet-hole through his head.

WASHINGTON, October 13. Mr. Vallandigham has been defeated as the Copperhead candidate for the Governor of Ohio. Pennsylvania Governor Curtin has been reelected. LOUISVILLE, Friday, Oct. 9. Gen. CROOK, commanding a brigade of cavalry twelve miles beyond Franklin, yesterday afternoon, came up with a portion of WHARTON'S rebel cavalry. Sharp fighting ensued. the result of which was 125 rebels killed and wounded, 300 taken prisoners, and four pieces of cannon captured. The rebels are in full retreat, and our forces are pursuing. No casualties to the Federals are reported.

WASHINGTON, October 12. The rebels have been driven from Brandy Station, Virginia. NEW YORK, October 12. A series of robberies have been committed on the Hudson River Railroad. One of the victims is a Mr. LANDON, who testifies that on Wednesday night last, he left this City on an Express train of the Hudson River Railroad, bound for Montreal. While approaching Yonkers, two ruffians entered the car, dragged LANDON therefrom and threw him into Spuyten Duyvil Creek. The injuries he received, together with the cold bath, rendered him insensible for a time. When he recovered he found that his pocket-book, containing over SX 800 in money, was missing.

WASHINGTON, October 11. The Army of the Potomac has reportedly withdrawn to the north side of the Rappahannock River. There has been an attack on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, near Germantown. WASHINGTON, Saturday, Oct. 10. The Republican Extra says Government has received dispatches dated Chattanooga, Oct. 9, and from officers on duty at ROSECRANS' headquarters. also official dispatches from Nashville, all containing reports most encouraging for the National cause. The forces under Gen. MITCHELL overtook the rebel cavalry on the 6th inst. below Shelbyville, and a battle immediately ensued, resulting in a complete rout of the enemy.

WASHINGTON, October 10. A sharp fight occurred to-day with the rebel Stuart's cavalry at Robertson's River. There has been a skirmish between the rebels and Gen. Burnside's forces at Blue Springs, Tennessee. Gen. ROSECRANS' headquarters, October 6. QN Not a man was injured by the rebel batteries yesterday. Our men are not annoyed by the long range firing in the least, and go about their work the same as ever. The negro boys continued to play marbles while the bombardment was going on, which is some evidence that a very extensive alarm did not exist. RICHMOND, October 10. President Jefferson Davis reviewed the rebel army before Chattanooga to-day.

WASHINGTON, October 9. Gen. BANKS remains in New-Orleans. As a line of telegraph is laid down as the Union army advances, the Commanding General of the Department will have rapid communication with the army in the field. To enable civilians of Ohio employed in divisions of the army to come home to vote, the Governor has ordered State agents at all points to issue half-fare tickets. It is estimated that fully 3,000 voters will thus be added to the poll.

WASHINGTON, October 8. The rebel rams in the Mersey have reportedly been placed under the supervision of English officials. NASHVILLE, Wednesday, Oct. 7. Up to a late hour this evening information from Chattanooga at Murfreesboro did not tell of a general engagement. The two armies still remain in front of each other, fortifying. Irregular firing was of constant occurrence. There were some movements being made on the part the enemy that seemed odd and mysterious, but not positively threatening. Neither railroad nor telegraph communication is open to Stevenson, Ala., from Nashville. but the news brought is not depressing.

WASHINGTON, October 7. MAILS FOR THE BLOCKADING FLEET. -- The United States transport Massachusetts will sail in a few days from the Philadelphia Navy-yard for the South Atlantic Blockading Squadron. Letters, papers and parcels, properly directed to the officers and crew, will be cheerfully forwarded if sent to the Philadelphia Navy-Yard before the departure of the vessel. There are some 30 vessels attached to the fleet now, the officers and crews of which anxiously expect news and newspapers from their friends at the North.

WASHINGTON, October 6. The frigate Ironsides was attacked yesterday by a rebel vessel and torpedo in Charleston Harbor, in the night. An engagement has reportedly occurred at Blue Springs, Tennessee. CHARLESTON, Thursday, Oct. 1. The firing during to-day has been heavier than for several weeks past. The enemy has been steadily pounding at the ruins of Sumter from his old batteries on Morris Island, beyond Wagner. His fire was chiefly at Sumter, but he also shelled Fort Johnson. Our batteries and Fort Moultrie replied with a brisk and steady fire. All quiet to-night.

WASHINGTON, Monday October 5. The railroad bridge south of Murfreesboro, Tennessee, has reportedly been destroyed by rebels. Rebel batteries have opened on Gen. Rosecrans' forces at Chattanooga. A letter from Dalton,. Ga., Sept. 26, published in the Richmond Dispatch on Saturday, says: QN The over-sanguine multitude will be somewhat disappointed to know that the chances of Gen. BRAGG taking Gen. ROSECRANS' army is no easy job. Although his losses have been heavy, he yet has a very formidable army. QN The two armies were still confronting each other at last accounts at Chattanooga. ROSECRANS, it is said, has established three lines in front of the town.

WASHINGTON, October 4. The frigate Ironsides was attacked yesterday by a rebel vessel and torpedo in Charleston Harbor, in the night. NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sunday, Oct. 4. An explosion occurred near Bridgeport. A train of twenty army wagons laded with ammunition had camped near the city for the night. Two negroes quarrelled, one of whom accidentally threw a flame among the ammunition, causing it to explode and communicate to the other ammunition. Immediately after wagon after wagon caught fire, the teamsters and their attendants leaping for their lives. Nine or ten are killed and double that wounded. The fire finally reached the magazine, exploding it.

WASHINGTON, October 3. The president to-day issued a proclamation appointing November 26 as Thanksgiving Day. McMinnville, Tennessee, has been attacked by rebels. ST. JOHNS, N.F., Thursday, Oct. 1. The heavy rains of last week occasioned a terrible freshet in the rivers on this island, which has done so much damage to the telegraph wires that they could not be worked for eight days.

WASHINGTON, October 2. There has reportedly been a success cavalry engagement at Anderson's Cross-roads, Kentucky. The crews of the gunboats Reliance and Satellite, captured on the Rappahannock, the boat's crew from the Wabash, taken in Charleston Harbor, and the boat's crew of the Niphon, captured at New Inlet, N.C., have arrived here as paroled prisoners. They number in all about sixty. Accompanying them is a deserter from the Richmond City Battalion, named CHARLES HUTCHINS, formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. He says that there are from 10,000 to 11,000 rebel troops in the neighborhood of Richmond.

NEW YORK, October 1. To-day there was a reception for the officers of the Russian fleet by the military and civil authorities of New York. LOUISVILLE, Saturday, Sept. 26. Gen. BURNSIDE was at Knoxville yesterday. Military authorities here say that BURNSIDE did not know of the impending battle between ROSECRANS and BRAGG, and could not have reinforced ROSECRANS if he had. The battle had been long concluded before the news reached BURNSIDE. The rebel telegraph line from the Gap to Morristown is not in order, but there is telegraphic communication between Knoxville and Morristown.
